is the idea here that you are configuring the secure openldap endpoint as early as possible in bootstrap ?

( because on host-unlock (lines 43-44) is going to do this as well ? )

Correct. The reason we do part of the LDAP schema configuration update in host-install is to have a staged approach and not overload and impact execution performance in host-unlock by applying all the changes at once.
Regarding host-unlock changes, lines 43-44, they refer to update of the certificate and key file locations, meaning the directory path where they were copied, whereas in host-install we copy the new openldap certificate and key files to a directory location, such as "/etc/openldap/certs".

shouldn't this step sequentially go before above step (lines 37-39) ?

Maybe you should combine the bootstrap use case into a single bullet with two subbullets describing required openldap work, organized in the sequence they need to occur

isn't the use case here "initial" controller-0 host-unlock ?

Again, maybe we should have single bullet for "initial controller-0 host-unlock" with 3x subbullets describing required openldap work, organized in the sequence they need to occur
e.g. shouldn't cert-mon happen first ? ... as it triggers the other steps
using Cert-Manager CRDs, which will be auto-configured at bootstrap time, and detected by CertMon that will use sysinv internal REST APIs to configure the openldap certificate.
as the new secure endpoint for openldap/slapd is not yet being used.  In future next step, when SSSD client is introduced, security will be enhanced with use of HTTPS for openldap/slapd.

Suggested Reword:

This story addresses this issue by updating system bootstrap to:
- create a system-local-ca 'tls'-type SECRET to be the top of the 
  platform certificate chains, and 
- create a cert-manager `ClusterIssuer` that uses system-local-ca for signing of certificates.  

The system-local-ca 'tls'-type SECRET will be auto-populated with the K8S Root CA certificate and key, such that the default platform certificate configuration will use a single Root CA for all Platform Certificates (i.e. k8s, starlingx, registry).  Note that the K8S Root CA is either auto-generated by the system at startup, or specified by user as a bootstrap playbook override.

REWORD:

Have we confirmed this?
Do we move the configuration over automatically during upgrades? Are the certs regenerated? 
We might need to engage with someone in the upgrade team to confirm this and if we need some more upgrade-specific changes in ansible.

I have further looked at the bootstrap.yml playbook and playbooks that use it.

The upgrade_platform.yml and restore_platform.yaml playbooks both use the bootstrap playbook with mode = 'restore', which is different than the mode using during bootstrap where mode = 'bootstrap'.

Inside the playbook many operations are only performed during bootstrap and skipped ruing upgrade / restore, such as:

# Create DC CA and set up subcloud admin endpoint certificates for bootstrap mode.
- block:
  - name: Create distributed cloud CA
    include_tasks: create_dc_ca.yml
    when: distributed_cloud_role == 'systemcontroller'

  - name: Set up subcloud admin endpoints certificates if host is a subcloud
    include_role:
      name: common/setup-subcloud-adminep-certs
    vars:
      ansible_become: yes
    when: distributed_cloud_role == 'subcloud'

  when: mode == 'bootstrap'

Having said that, it seems to me like we should do the same and skip the creating of system-local-ca issuer and platform certificates for the upgrade path as well, as changing these certificates during upgrade may cause unexpected consequences to users (losing external access for instance). 

It seems safer to let users upgrade first and then migrate certificates with the migrate_platform_certificates_to_certmanager.yml playbook at a later point.

Let me know what you think.

Hi Sabeel,

1. I think we should let users upgrade first and manually run the migrate-certificates playbook when they decide to. My reasoning for that is that they may have tools using external access to starlingx and they expect that to keep working after a system upgrade. I think cert-manager adoption should be a deliberate step for the upgrade path. 

As I said before, the upgrade playbook should skip the tasks from the bootstrap playbook that create cert-manager Issuer and certificates, following the example of 'Create distributed cloud CA' tasks.

2. As for point #1, the bootstrap playbook will skip the tasks from the bootstrap playbook that create cert-manager Issuer and certificates, so certificates and secrets will not get recreated. 

I don't think we need to do anything particular for configs to get saved during upgarde. Cert-manage certificates are saved as k8 secrets, they will remain unchanged even after upgrade.


Please clarify if I have misunderstood your questions.

There are two use cases to consider.
1. Upgrading from current stx 6 to stx 7 --> where we go from not having the config we want to the state we want the config (in which case, users can run migrate playbook). We may also need to consider what happens if users dont run the migrate playbook -- perhaps we should run the migrate-playbook from inside the upgrade-playbook to make sure the platform is in a state we expect it to be?
2. Upgrading from stx 7 to future releases --> will the configs get saved and moved to platform after upgrades automatically? This is what I was thinking needs some more investigation.
Good point Sabeel. I will try and confirm with the upgrade folks.

Not sure this statement makes sense. cert-mon runs after the controller unlock. By this time, all the ansible-playbook scripts would have completed the job. Can you confirm what you mean by this statement? Do we need some cert-mon code changes specific to this feature?
As discussed, we will go with original proposal in cert-mon instead of something during bootstrap.
Do you want me to refresh the review with this listed under 'alternative approaches' ?

OK makes sense.
Another option is to consider putting the two commands (https-enabled=true and certificate-install commands) as part of the bootstrap (before the controller unlock). This would mean you dont have to do anything in cert-mon.

Certificates and secrets for the rest/api and registry.local certificates are created during ansible bootstrap. 

Then there's the restart triggered by host-unlock.

When cert-mon starts up, after the host-unlock, it starts its watchers to watch for following secret events. As these certificate secrets were created before cert-mon's startup, it is not going to trigger the 'certificate-install' for them, as it starts up, only if an update happens to the certificate secrets.

I want to make use of cert-mon to do the 'certificate-install' of the certificate secrets. That would require a small change to cert-mon.
Will this impact Horizon GUI?  Do we need any changes in Horizon?

We don't need changes to horizon is already supports enabling HTTPS as per current procedure in https://docs.starlingx.io/security/kubernetes/enable-https-access-for-starlingx-rest-and-web-server-endpoints.html

However, I'm adding a new patchset to add horizon as documentation and end-user impact.

Thanks for pointing it out.

Do we know if this will impact end users?  For instance, if an end user has scripts or integrated with other systems, will they be impacted?  Do we need to notify the community of this behavior change?

Yes, you are correct. Users using automated scripts are likely to need to update their connection config. 

I have listed it under 'developer impact', please see if that's appropriate.
I have just sent out an email to the community as well

So dos this have the effect that vswitch manifests are now turned off during patching?
If a system wants to have vswitch on does it require a second lock/unlock after patching is completed to re-enable and re-run vswitch manifests

This ensures that the vswitch will be enabled or disabled based on the vswitch_type != 'none' in the absence of the enabled hieradata and the vswitch_class will still be provided by the non-patched sysinv, so it won't break on a openstack deployment scenario. 
Basically we are keeping the manifest the way it was prior to hybrid cluster changes in the absence of the plugin hieradata.

I don't think we need a second lock/unlock after patching to have vswitch enabled if it was already enabled prior to the patch apply, but to get HC support (enable/disable vswitch based on host labels) we do.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
Wouldn't it be better to use something like:

$enabled = ($::platform::params::vswitch_type != 'none'),

In this case, when vswitch_type is none the enabled param is false, otherwise it is true.

Be aware that a puppet variable can not be reassigned once it was previously assigned.
You probably want to do something like: https://github.com/starlingx/stx-puppet/blob/master/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/containerd.pp#L3

The IP table rules handle internal port ranges with "-" while the external ports ranges it handles using ":", so I did this replace to then just put the range in the rules, or if you think that it will be better, I can split it by ":" and replace the ":" by "-" when I return it to apply in the IP table rules.

The rule creation parameters for fip 8.8.8.8, external 2:4, internal 5:7 and local ip 9.9.9.9 seems like that:

-d 8.8.8.8/32 --dport 2:4 -j DNAT --to-destination 9.9.9.9:5-7'

to avoid repeating the ":" in the --to-destination parameter, the IP table command handle the parameter with IP and port split by ":" and the port range split by "-".

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: @Sean, Can we merge this to unblock downstream jobs? tox targets can't run with current released 2.3.0.

Agree with Sean that the most ideal will be bump version when actual function changes, but for heat wallaby release, not sure how long that means. So +1 to agree on targeting downstream CI automation breakdown if that's appropriate and acceptable to release rule.

As is discussed locally, having release for the updated tox.ini is not aligned with the current workflow for cycle-with-intermediary .

For cycle-with-intermediary, we create multiple releases during the cycle and cut off the branch from the last release. Because tox.ini is updated after the branch cutoff, there is no trigger to get a release including the updated tox.ini .

I'm removing -1 because this is the only solution we have now, but this is not really specific to this release or to python-heatclient and I'm afraid we need to repeat the same in the future, unless we come up with the way to fix misalignment of current release workflow and usage of tox.ini a released version.
Not sure why this is only an issue for python-heatclient, but fair enough.
There are no functional changes included to be released. This should wait until there are actual changes merged to stable/wallaby.

While I can see the merit in only releasing tags on functional changes, we introduced the tox change to prevent CI failures.
https://github.com/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/3c5a604949dcc5a94c1c814861e8b910832cc53f

It would be great to not have to diverge downstream / upstream repos for the sake of tox. 

I personally think there is no harm in releasing as per this review, and we keep this issue in mind moving forward to avoid situations like this in the future.

Though there are no functional changes, https://github.com/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/3c5a604949dcc5a94c1c814861e8b910832cc53f required by tox targets merged quite late and breaks downstream CI automation.

We do distribute source for a release and downstream runs tox jobs on it. Unless they provide a local constraints file it uses the upstream ones. I agree this is global problem across all client releases that should be addressed.

Though this is a tactical solution to address that problem for python-heatclient, I don't see any reason to block this patch (we've had plenty of releases without any functionality addition).
The whole shade CI seems broken for a long time, not sure if it is worth the effort to revive it or if we should rather work towards retirement

This is not to update vnf_instance, but to update the resouceChanges in Vnflcm_op_occ, which needs to be obtained from vnf_instance, so it is processed here. When rolling back, you need to obtain the information to be rolledback from the resourceChanges of vnflcm_op_occ.
I understand there is a disagreement about rollback design.

I need to know what resource has been modified by change_vnfpkg but it has not been successful. When I rollback, I can roll back the resource to the previous vnfd settings. During rollback, only the data of vnflcm_op_occ is known, so it is only known from resourceChanges which VDUs were updated by change_vnfpkg but the update failed, so that they will be rolled back.
If I can't use the resourceChanges to store failed VDUs information, do you have any better suggestion? I can change my code in next PS.
resoureChanges in Vnflcm_op_occ is set when the process success.

About rollback, I think it is enough to do stack update with original template and original parameters simply. original template can be get from original vnfd. I think values for original parameters can be get from existing VnfInstance object (from DB). Note that contents of VnfInstance object (from DB) are before change_vnfpkg starting.

The rollingupdate upgrade_type should update VDU one by one. And the rollback operation also should rollback one by one. Currently, the code is satisfactory by design.
If it must be modified, I need to re-test, which is a waste of time and may not catch up with the release on Friday. If you really want to modify it, we can discuss the modification plan in the next version.

why not use _make_instatiated_vnf_info ?
should use _make_instantiated_vnf_info. even if there is a reason, should modify _make_instantiated_vnf_info. note that there are some treatments for other APIs (ex. heal).

_make_instantiated_vnf_info is the method that it makes instantiatedVnfInfo from current heat resources. It does not matter what was updated. (unchanged part is unchanged)
Originally it is enough to call _make_instantiated_vnf_info at last of each API by design. I mean it should be no problem to call _make_instantiated_vnf_info.

rollingupdate does not change any network info, I only modify the updated vdu information and storage information, I don't think it is necessary to regenerate instantiated_info. This doesn't match my original SS design, and when I started the design, the method hadn't been uploaded to the master branch, so I didn't refer to it. If I changed it to _make_instantiated_vnf_info, I need time to unblock and test whether this part of the code matches my operation again, which will take extra time. If necessary, I can refactor it together the next time I add the blue-green update method.

I know that `_make_instantiated_vnf_info` can handle the action of change_vnfpkg, but I am not sure if it can handle the data I want when I rollback. It will take a long time to reconsider the design, so I will not fix this part in this patch. And it doesn't affect other APIs currently. I think I'll refactor this part together in the next update for blue-green.

nodepool/driver/aws/adapter.py.message: Well, that creates an AwsInstance object instead of an AwsResource; which is probably fine, but it may have some extra requirements which I wouldn't want to guarantee we could fulfill here, since we may be dealing with leaked instances so all the requirements may not be present.

One thought about quotas. AWS has separated quotas for some instance families. For the start I think this quota code is fine andcovers the most used instance types.

I wonder if we could improve that later by mapping the quotas to codes-standard for the standard images and cores-p for p instances and so on. This way we could generically cover the individual quotas for the currently 8 different instance quotas.
Yeah, the quota system is pretty flexible (thanks!), I think that might be a nice improvement.

Internal AWS implementation detail: AFAICT, this is actually implemented in AWS by booting an instance from this image, then they run some stuff on it, and take a snapshot.

An interesting side effect of this is that you can't really upload an image that doesn't closely correspond to an image they already support natively.  Especially the kernel must be a supported version.
Why is there a snapshot if we are directly uploading an AMI? Is this intentional due to some api oddity or is this something that should be removed?

I thought about that, but the tagging action in uploadImage is so straightforward (because we actually have the IDs in that case) and this is so complex (because we have to guess them!) that it seemed better to have different routines, even if they are slightly redundant.  Hopefully these are noops 99% of the time.

This method and the next one seem a bit at odds with what the uploadImage does. It applies tags to both AMIs and snapshots. Should we maybe call these methods from uploadImage instead to brute for this a bit more?
Why not limit this to a few thousand entries?
Should we check if it is a snapshot before removing the flag?
This bit was copy-pasta from the old driver.  That does sound like a good improvement.

roles/limit-log-file-size/README.rst.message: This might read better as "checks the size of each log file"

I don't really get what the soft size does over the warning size.  They both give you a warning.  I think you have to be careful about how much you warn people, because the more you do it, the less effective it becomes.

I would reduce this to just warning level; and have it much closer to the hard failure limit.  Like 950mb warning and 1g failure.  or maybe even better be relative; e.g. 95% of the failure limit.
I will also fix this, the additional warning level is only necessary for the transition phase for the projects. And will will do it in our fork.
That was discussed in ci team in our company, I will take your concerns and discuss it within the team.

Regarding the default limit values, they can be configured per needs when the role is used. 
I set those as default value big enough so that most of the projects should not be affect even with the default.

roles/limit-log-file-size/defaults/main..message: All the variables need to follow https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/policy.html#role-variable-naming-policy, please rename

roles/limit-log-file-size/tasks/main.yam.message: I have tried the same code as you proposed, actually it would generate "\\n", i.e. literal "\n" in text. And with a var of "\n" works around that issue.

This is missing a "the".  At a minimum we should fix this.

We know it has failed because it's in a fail task and i think saying the files exceed the limit implies they need to be reduced.  Might read better as just simply

 The following files have exceeded the log file limit of {{ ... }}:
 ... list ...

similarly here, i think keep it short and keep all the info at the top

 The following files are approaching the maximum size ({{ limit_log_file_size_fail }})

The actual warning threshold size doesn't seem to actually matter to the end-user reading this message.  This is why I think it would be better make as a % of the hard limit.  This way you could simply say

 The following file sizes are more than 95% of the hard limit {{ limit_log_file_size_fail }}

(saying 95% "full", rather than say "within 5%" gives more of a sense of exhausting resources -- like when you look at df output)
there was a typo: fill -> feel.

Done. I fill with the percentage would make the implemention more complex, when the limit is configured as a string like "1g/500m" instead of just a number. I would rather keep it simple and flexible.

This doesn't seem to make sense -- "any log file" != "job-output.txt, job-output.json"

Why wouldn't you want this matching every file?  Isn't that the point?

It is possible that the project build might want to write project specific log files to the same directory during the build, and we should allow them to be big. The intention for this change is to limit the zuul output log files (job-output.txt, job-output.json) size.

It is also a good idea to parameterize the patter with a var.
mean while, I also have some other fixes that were detected in our local fork deployment.

I think this significantly changes the operation of the role; the name nor the readme does not reflect that this is not a generic role to look at all log files.  That is my immediate -1 issue with it.  

This is supposed to be a very general repository so my feeling is that restricting it is not quie right.  Perhaps you should parameterize the pattern and keep it generic, then you can add particular files to match at will?

technical-guides/unified-limits.rst.message: Debating if it might be helpful to mention oslo.limit here, imagining if someone new to keystone limits is reading this and this section talks all about limits. Their first question might be "so how do I do resource counting and enforcement?" before they've gotten to the "players involved" section.
Done
Sure, I'll add some foreshadowing here and delegate the details to below.

If I understand what you mean here, I think the Enforcer doesn't batch resource names for calls for limits with regard to keystone calls [1]. And I notice the keystone API doesn't let you filter limits by more than one resource [1], so to save round trips, you have to GET all the limits and do your own filtering. I'm thinking we should probably update Enforcer to do that. It would mean Enforcer has to do filtering on the returned limits resource names itself though ... but that's lighter than separate keystone calls for each resource name.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.limit/blob/562ada0e2d1353d1405a1215cb396b7e44e70a02/oslo_limit/limit.py#L319-L338
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html?expanded=list-registered-limits-detail#list-registered-limits
Ack

Right, but it could/should in the future. Writing new code to use this to be as batch-friendly in the future means we can get that gain if the underlying stuff does it correctly. So, write the code here to use the batching python interface, and leave the optimizations to the library maintainers.

I added this because I think nova, being a retrofit, probably doesn't (can't) use this as much as we might like. So to avoid someone learning by example from code that was a compromise, I wanted to say "if you can, batch it".
Thanks, this was left over from me originally being prescriptive and hypothetical, but changing to a relatable example instead.
Done

IMHO this comma was correct, as it delineates a non-restrictive phrase from the rest of the sentence.

https://www.grammarly.com/blog/comma-before-which/
Done

This is a conditional statement and thus this applies:

https://linguaholic.com/linguablog/comma-before-then/

It's apparently optional for implicit "then" usage, but I'm going to put the then in here and thus add back the comma. The one below this is a straight "if..then" conditional and thus needs it back as well.
Done

This is no longer correct I think. The workflow applies to the thing being done, in that it's "relevant" or "related".

It does not apply the workflow itself, as in taking action, which I think is what the sentence means with your edit. Now, this reads to me as if the library provides the quotas functionality itself, but it does not: it provides tooling (i.e. the workflow) for the service to implement and enforce quotas.
Done

also, it will be good to add a section here about what is the issue in existing quota mechanism projects has and how this unified limit can solve those. That will help projects to understand the requirement to move to the unified limit.

Even below sections are covering those in detail but having a list of issues in existing quota and how this unified limit can solve will be helpful to understand the further document.

Okay, I guess I didn't see this as a requirement, but more of a "if you're going to use unified limits, here are guidelines."

I definitely agree that anyone adding new quota stuff should use unified limits instead of growing something themselves at this point. Converting existing projects is nice, but I can imagine it's pretty low priority.

we can add the nova example here to know how to handle the existing APIs case. are not they recommended/planned to be deprecated with new microversion?

Also, the legacy way of defining the quota via conf file (like in nova case not sure if other projects also have that) is ignored if a unified limit is enabled.

These kinds of directions about what to do with the existing way of quota will be helpful. Or in detail what are the recommended migration plan so that we do not break existing users. I prefer it can be a separate section 'Migration Plan' or so.

Okay, I'm not sure we can be too prescriptive about how they should deprecate the existing stuff for all projects, and I would expect that to be covered under standard API and deprecation guidelines. However, good point about providing some guidance about how to handle the new case. Specifically, *not* proxying existing quota set apis to keystone is a good example.

> Also, the legacy way of defining the quota via conf file (like in nova case not sure if other projects also have that) is ignored if a unified limit is enabled.

I thought I covered this in the "All or none" section, but will try to strengthen the wording there.
sure, at least we can tell 'make sure you are not breaking the exiting way' they do it via keeping or deprecating the existing APIs is all their call(I agree with you on this).

Do you think we should provide a API spec (or a standard way of their name/request/response body) for such new APIs so that it can be consistent for all project implementing new one. glance API format as mentioned as example can be good to recommend?

That's really not doable for nova, and so I would expect not doable for other projects either without substantial needless API churn. So, because I don't want nova to have to do that, I'll say I'd rather not push people to rewrite towards some new goal if they already have one. Do you feel strongly otherwise?

yeah for nova or any projects having existing APIs are not doable but if for any proejcts impelementing quota first time for them it will be useful that what APIs they can provide to get quota like glance did. But may be you can better judge if that is something is required or just a good API to have?

Examining the train provider failure I have discovered that the tempest *patches* are the culprit. 
This is the gist of it: Tempest is branch less, changes there impact all releases.

When we run train job or any other, it will use the new code at some point. That would be fine, but when the build process starts, other patches are applied, those supplied in rpm. That's when the error shows up:

----

DEBUG: + /usr/bin/git apply --index -
DEBUG: error: patch failed: tools/generate-tempest-plugins-list.py:54
DEBUG: error: tools/generate-tempest-plugins-list.py: patch does not apply
----

I'm not certain, but it seems possible the we are dealing with merge problem here.
One of the tempest patches, possibly: 

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/820270
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/810808

Would have to touch some file altered by the patches in rmp. 

But that's just my best hypothesis.

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request..message:
We've had to deal with cases where re-quoting WSGI's unquoted line leads to SignatureMismatch errors (see https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1884991) -- the advantage of RAW_PATH_INFO is that it's *exactly* whatever the client put on the wire.

But, that was for v2 signatures -- and sure enough, the AWS docs are pretty darn clear for v4. The "Example: PUT Object" section is particularly compelling, indicating that you can send something like

 PUT test$file.text HTTP/1.1

with a signature where the canonical request looks more like

 PUT
 /test%24file.text
 ...

One minor nit: Python's quote() function already has the right safe characters:

> Letters, digits, and the characters '_.-~' are never quoted. ... The optional safe parameter specifies additional ASCII characters that should not be quoted — its default value is '/'.

though it's fair to argue that explicit is better than implicit here.

gerrit-server/src/main/java/com/google/g.message:
In InnoDB, the table is stored clustered on the primary key.

It would be more efficient to make file_id the primary key and then to make a secondary unique index on account_id, change_id, patch_set_id, file_id.

So:

  PRIMARY KEY file_id;
  CREATE UNIQUE INDEX account_change_patch_idx
    ON account_patch_reviews (
        account_id, change_id, patch_set_id, file_id);

If I were gonna nitpick further, I'd want to see if we always are doing lookups with account_id. I'm guessing we don't - and that change_id, patch_set_id, account_id would be better (account_id basically being in the index to make it covering, rather than to increase cardinality) I don't have any idea if that is true though.

tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py.message:
I'm worried about not having control over the string you can pass from the cli. It can be anything (even if we have enough doc covering the user workflow): not against the feature but, do you think we want to have a validation on what can be passed ?
I was thinking more about an array of allowed options that can be reduced to a string and set as the extra_var mentioned here.
Thanks Francesco. I've added the --force option which is now required to use --cephadm-extra-args

First, thank you for taking some time to write this explanation and the reason of having this command.
The purpose of the patch looks good to me, we're going to add more flexibility on the client and avoiding tons of patchs just to decline the tripleoclient to cephadm, and yeah, we don't have that python library in the undercloud, we can't import cephadm stuff and validate the input/options.
From the list above, the right choice should be: you're an expert user, you know what you're doing (injecting parameters to the cephadm bootstrap, that can be buggy itself), I have to warn you that I (tripleo) have no control over those options, so --force (the equivalent of the ceph flag: --yes-i-really-mean-it) is sufficient.
I don't want to block this patch though, so feel free to add this to the backlog for a follow-up.

I think what you're asking is an appropriate question when you see something like this.

I added this very open ended option because keeping up with every option from "cephadm bootstrap --help" would be a never ending task and eventually someone might need an option we haven't mirrored here. Just like how ansible has --extra-vars which could be anything.

Doing what is done here is a security "no no" in a client/server model where we're worried the client could attack the server, but in this case the admin would only use it to attack themselves on a system where they already have root that they have not deployed yet. It's an expert option and if you mess up your system it's on you, just like how you can "rm -rf /" yourself.  I could add a "--force" option which is required in order to use this argument to imply you're forcing something if you use this.

Maintaining up to date validation for this is tricky.

If we required cephadm to be installed in the undercloud, then we could call "cephadm bootstrap --help" and check that the options are the same or we could try interacting with it on a python level to see if it's a valid parser_bootstrap object: 

https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/master/src/cephadm/cephadm#L8229

However, I think both of those options are too expensive. 

We get a lot of power on the cheap with this feature, but yes, with that power comes responsibility.

I think our options are below:

1. Require --force and but in the doctext for it that this could result in a failed deploy. 

2. Build a list from cephadm's parser_bootstrap today that we maintain over time.

3. Keep the feature as is

4. Abandon the patch

Anything I might have missed thought?

specs/build_distribution_packages.rst.message: I think it might be worthwhile to expand on the problem description here. There are at least 4 use cases I sent in that email. You obviously don't need to include all of them, or group them that way - but I think describing the different reasons we need packages will go a long way to helping folks like Vincent understand the why - and will help us to check that our implementation meets all of the desired use cases.
Also, having concrete examples (and not just the theoretical cases) would be a good thing :-)

From what I hear from packagers, http://openbuildservice.org/ is far better than launchpad. You can either host your own or use the hosted service at https://build.opensuse.org/ (and yes, it can build Debian and CentOS packages from one source)

It's worth including that one of the reasons Launchpad isn't a great solution is that it's an async service - and also that we already have our own massively scalable build farm - so submitting an async request to someone else's build farm - especially when that build farm can get slammed during releases - is a little sillly.

I do think that listing OBS is worth doing. However, I'll go ahead and say that one of my personal issues with OBS is that it uses its own meta packaging, unless something has changed, which would decrease our ability to collaborate with downstream packaging. That said - since it does debs and rpms already, and since it's possible to run one locally, it's certainly worth investigation.
Could not agree more. :)

I'm not convinced we always want to do that. Repos live forever in openstack, and creating a repo is a heavyweight task. At least one of our use cases would benefit from the ability to also build packages from things where we do not host a copy of a packaging repo.
i'd like to see more details about the script, as packaging is not an easy automated task. It's not dependencies but setup config script, ensure services are started, etc...
So it will be just a basick package, no postinst tasks for example to configure settings and start services?

The packaging is up to the repository it is stored in -- the script is only concerned with building the package, and since it will not install the package, it will not execute the postinst script to configure settings or start services.

The packaging itself will not be done by the script. The script is only concerned about building the package itself, so building a source tree, installing the required build-time dependencies and then running rpmbuild or dpkg-buildpackage.
No? I'd imagine that we might want a server to host repositories?

For this specification only, I was going with the plan that we would store the resultant packages where we currently store logs and artifacts for existing jobs, and then look at changing that for the follow-up specification to publish the packages.
Which kind of testing is going to be performed? Ubuntu has the autopkgtests, i don't know if there is something equivalent on CentOS.
My initial plan was to check that package builds are repeatable and gives the same (modulo timestamps and so on) results.

Over the years, I've seen very little contributions from upsteam OpenStack to Debian (did I miss some? Please point at them...). It's really easy to contribute to Debian, sending patches through the bug tracker or otherwise. So reading "OpenStack is at the mercy of upstream distributions" as if distributions like Debian or Ubuntu had an evil agenda against upstream OpenStack doesn't read well at all, especially considering that I did some package changes to accommodate OpenStack infra and probably Canonical team did as well. We'd be happy to do more if asked. So please rephrase this in a more friendly manner.

Indeed, mercy is generally a positive quality and we expect it from distro maintainers when it is possible. But sometimes the policy that a distro employs to protect the general user will in fact be harmful to us. That said, I think we need to make it a part of this policy that a bug is open in the distro, and patches that we carry are submitted before we carry them in our own repo.
Ok, fair enough. I'll be happy to help having this done.

By at the mercy, I mean of timing. We're running a live production system, there are times when waiting for the distro to apply a patch is unworkable - even though that is out goal.

So we're at their mercy. It's usually very good mercy - but we still have to plan for the moments where we need something before it lands.
For this, we have Debian stable-backports, or Ubuntu cloud archive. I don't think any of the distributions I mentioned would refuse contribution.

We need for the nova developers to be able to say, in the context of OpenStack development "nova needs libvirt version X", for us to be able to service that request, and to forward that information to the distros in such a way that the next version of the distro has that version of the dependency package.

We can do this with python/pip today, but we cannot do it with C-based packages. It's mostly ok- we don't want to do it very often - but again, it comes up sometimes and we need to have a mechanism to do it.

The answer for an openstack developer can't be "go get UCA to update their dependencies" - because it would actually be inappropriate for UCA to accept that patch, since it's not actually even tested yet.
Same here, this could be done in upstream distributions. Before such thing is attempted, I'd like you to point at attempts to get the improvements happen upstream.

Right - but we don't know if it's the right thing to ask the distros to do. If we can't make the packages locally, we can't test that it's a good idea, so we'd be asking the distro to make a change in a flag or config option that we have not yet vetted. That would be very rude of us.
If we need zuul or nodepool to be uploaded in Debian or Ubuntu, that can happen easily. I am hereby offering my help to sponsor such an upload.

We appreciate that help - but that's not the point here. We want to deploy zuul and nodepool literally on every single patch that lands. We do not want to land 20 patches, then make a release, then package that release, then upload that release to debian, then wait for the debian build farm to build it, then deploy it. We want to approve a patch and have it automatically be deployed into production instantly.

We ALSO want tagged releases of zuul and nodepool to be uploaded to distros so that people who are not us can run them at a rate which is different than every single patch.
PPA are Ubuntu specific things. That's not a solution, but more troubles. Why not just trying to upload to Debian (which pushes to Ubuntu on its next cycle), and to Fedora / RDO?

Hum... How should I put this... Nooooooooo! (aaaarg ... dying....) ! :)

Seriously, OBS is really bad, and we should avoid it at all costs. At Mirantis, we're kind of locked-in with it, and it's currently painful to get out of it to use standard tooling of distributions (like sbuild or delorean). Let's not repeat this kind of mistake twice.
Again - this is a list of alternatives.
note: The use of VMs in OBS also prevents builds to access the network in order to guarantee reproducible builds (though it also makes packaging some things like hadoop+Maven hard)
If you wanted support to help do things, you can add my name.
Do we need to define what the git repo looks like? Some spec for that?  We currently have openstack-infra/zuul-packaging.
I think having a debian directory/or a .spec at the root of the repo is what we want to do here. You're right in that we might want to codify this in the spec.

This is called sbuild. You don't need to write such a script (and reinvent the wheel), just use what's already available and widely used in Debian. Fedora / RDO guys are using Delorean or Mock. I'd be for using what distributions are using, and eventually contribute if you see some missing features (which so far, I haven't from the Debian side).
using sbuild may be the answer- but sbuild itself is something that we will need a script to drive.

which 'script' are we talking about? Something like git-buildpackage(-rpm), dpk-build, etc.  Or is this something infra sees about building?  

My person view, is this is configured by the build job, allowing builders to pick their tooling of choice.
'said script' here refers to the script we develop in the first work item -- if you have a better idea for wording to make that clear, I'm all ears.

Not for Infra packages. For infra packages there will be one script that will work one and only one way and it will not be configurable.

For general use of the infrastructure for other things - awesome.

We should call out the difference.
Example might be required, but that could open a can of worms.
Job templates are pretty well understand, I think. Or are you asking something else?
But new base DIBs required in nodepool?  EG: cache build dependencies before builds or even HTTP proxy for caching upstream yum / apt.
I wasn't planning on wanting to requiring extra machines such as local mirrors or such to keep the complexity of this spec down.
Talking to -infra about this, we decided using the ubuntu-trusty dib would be a good step.  Then, building some chroots atop of that jenkins node.
Perhaps listing existing toolsets from Debian / RHEL that does this.  EG: package lint...

linting a package is not testing it.

My point is we can build something a few times and see that it gets built correctly a number of times. As I said above, better wording would be welcome.

Err, linting is static analysis, which is a form of test. But I do see where you're are getting at. I believe we should look at DEP8 and autopkgtest as  a way to leverage existing tests on packages we just want to rebuild. Also that will be rather nice for any packages we create, as we can submit them to Debian and Ubuntuwith tests built in.

Instead of passing in a list of names, pass in a hash of hashes like {'openstack/foo' => {source=>'https://git.openstack.org...', github=>'https://github.com'}} and then use create_resources to process the overall hash.

It might be better to make this a bit more general, so it can be used again later without having to copy and paste lots of lines.

modules/openstack_project/files/docker_r.message:
For what its worth, the registry does not support shared backends (they have explicitly said they do not support NFS[0] in the past) *unless* it is object storage. So ceph-s3/swift/s3/gcs etc is all supported.

Now some people have been able to get NFS to work (which seems like the same for AFS), it was said to be not supported and untested.

[0] https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/15833#issuecomment-153115574
I think this is something that is important to raise.  I wonder if this will create issues for us.  Could we instead rely on object storage from infrastructure donors?
we could, but object storage isn't going to replicate as well as a pre-region docker registry pull-cache. The objects would end up being pulled from other regions

 erase_errors[dev.name] = "Secure erase failed: %s. Fall back to metadata erase also failed: %s"

Where the first error is kept from block 1450.

Good question Dmitry. My understanding is that if we just include errors from self._ata_erase(dev) in erase_errors[], with the way the code is currently written, this will cause an exception here even if destroy_disk_metadata runs successfully as the next step. 
I can think of two sample options here:
1) we assign the error from the fast path to a variable and include this error in the log message if destroy_disk_metadata fails as well (IIUC we can no longer access the attributes of the previous exception in the following one as it is no longer the right scope hence the extra variable).
2) we change the logic so that we don't raise an exception if erase_errors are not empty but we do it when destroy_disk_metadata fails instead (given it's the last thing we try). And then we can log all the errors recorded in erase_errors on failure.
What are your thoughts? My understanding is that _ata_erase(dev) will produce exceptions when called against an unsupported device so we probably don't want to fail out yet when that happens provided that the following metadata clean works.

ironic_python_agent/hardware.py.message: This may be useful to reference, specifically because ATA erase and any fallbacks should be parallelizedsince even ATA secure erase, on spinning devices can still be multi-hour operations.... If the device does not support rotating encryption keys or if it just has a null key set to begin with.

Thank you Julia, you raised a good point. 

I will start with two statements to set the context:

1) I don't have any first hand experience with devices that support ATA secure erase implemented as a long-running operation so haven't thought about this particular use case, my main goal was to help with NVMe+HDD scenario. I added ATA erase support thinking of it as an equivalent of NVMe erase for SATA SSDs thinking "why not help these cases too". You caught me out on the HDD use case! 😊

2) In the early days of working on this patch I did actually ask myself whether we need this to be parallel or not. Given I am thinking of this feature as a "hardware assisted" erase_devices_metadata, I figured I will use the same approach as erase_devices_metadata which doesn't use parallelism given the runtime is reasonably quick.

I see your point regarding parallelism. For this particular feature I'd be leaning towards saying that if a secure erase operation is long-running, it should not be a part of this cleaning mode whether it's using parallelism or not (and it belongs in erase_devices). My idea was to perform time-optimised cleaning - use fast, "hardware-accelerated" secure erasure methods where available (e.g. NVMe secure erase or ATA secure erase) and fall back to metadata clean if not. If a particular model of a storage device takes say 3 hours to clean with ATA erase, I think this is already breaking the promise of "express" erasure. Not using parallelism will make it blow out way more if we have say 16 of such devices in the system just as you pointed out (in which case we may be looking at 48 hours). 

If we are dealing with long-running ATA secure erase, I'd lean towards saying we shouldn't use it here, even if it's made run in parallel on each device in the system. The challenge there is - how would we know whether it's long running or not. With NVMes, IIRC at least some of them do actually report estimated erasure time if queried. Does such feature exist for ATA secure erase and if so do we know if it is dependable enough to build upon it? Any insights on this would be very helpful.

Without betting on the above information I see a couple potential ways forward:

1) we remove ATA erase from this feature entirely and try NVMe erase and fallback to metadata erase if NVMe erase isn't available.
Pros: we will not run into an issue where long-running ATA erase operations make erase_devices_express break it's "express" promise
Cons: we may prevent operators with SATA SSDs that support near-instant ATA erase and would *just work* as a part of this feature from fully utilising the features of their hardware

2) we keep it as-is and perhaps add a "known issue" with devices which only support long-running ATA secure erase. We could also add parallelism later as a bugfix as you suggested.
Pros: We retain support for SATA devices that are capable of fast and secure data erasure 
Cons: Operators may run into the issue where erase_devices_express isn't that express

3) we could make this behaviour configurable in some shape or form (even today global use of ATA secure erase could be disabled, avoiding this problem). If we have a dedicated option that can be overly complex (but more flexible).

Let me know your thoughts. I would also value feedback from Arne who is a likely user of this feature and from Dmitry and Iury who've been assisting me in implementing this.
